results.title: Landslides
results.brief_description: Landslides takes us on a breathtaking journey of discovery, into and through the human body, under the ground, into the outback, into the air, into outer space. It provides visceral shock as it probes body tissues and spaces, and cerebral delight as it weaves intriguingly around its central theme.

results.title: Landscape in stamps
results.creator_credit: Michael Reeves, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Poetry, music and the detail of postage stamps are combined to produce an essentially impressionistic view of New Zealand’s social and physical landscape. A new direction of stamp concept.

results.title: Landscape as Character
results.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.

constellations_primary.name: Landscape as character
constellations_primary.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

results.description:
Australia’s First Peoples are connected to Country through thousands of generations of kinship ties. We derive our identity, culture, law and knowledge from Country – something we express and uphold through moving image storytelling. Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.
description_for_label:

Through the screen, we’re able to tell our story of survival against the violence of colonisation, ensuring our connection and re-connection to Country endures from the past to today.

The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. For years, the Outback has dominated Australian screen stories, but representations have sprawled into the suburbs and cities, creating compelling and complex characters on our screens.

results.title: Landfill
results.brief_description: This film tells of an operation in the United States to dispose of solid waste with a minimum of danger to the environment and people. Refuse is transported to a site away from the cities where several large steep gullies have been excavated for the purpose of holding the waste material. When filled with refuse, the gullies are covered avoiding infestation by flies, rats and seagulls.

results.title: Landfall Asia
results.creator_credit: Gordon Sparling, Tim Wilson, William Canning and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A spring cruise to the Far East with three destroyers of the Royal Canadian Navy. The film follows the ships to the exotic ports of Japan, Hong Kong, Ceylon, Bangkok. Highlighted is the Commonwealth exercise, “Jetex,” a simulated naval engagement.

results.title: Land of the sleeping giant
results.creator_credit: Colin Ballantyne, Associated World Public Relations and Yalumba Vineyards
results.brief_description: The Yalumba Winery in the Barossa Valley, South Australia. Aboriginal legends of a sleeping giant surround the country where Samuel Smith planted the first vines in 1849. His descendants now own a large modern winery in Anguston. Many varieties of grapes are harvested, and the whole process of making, blending and bottling the various wines and spirits is shown. Scientific tests are carried out throughout and the brandies are subject to Government inspection. Narrated by Charles “Bud” Tingwell.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Ballantyne, Associated World Public Relations and Yalumba Vineyards

results.title: Land of the morning star
results.creator_credit: Mark Worth, Janet Bell and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Writer/director Mark Worth has created a fascinating documentary about the oft forgotten western region of the island of Papua (also known as Netherlands New Guinea, West Papua, Irian Jaya and Papua). This film provides insight into the history of “West Papua” and its flag “The Morning Star”. Currently ruled by Indonesia, the film details political activist’s struggle for independence and their forced exile from a climate of fervent Indonesian nationalism. The film reveals a turbulent history in which Australia, the US and the UN have played a part. Narrated by Rachel Griffiths, music composed by David Bridie. A National Interest Program from Film Australia produced with assistance from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
